Description: Remains of a netted bag (used for carrying a pot) in undyed linen, now grey-buff in colour. In the main area of the bag, lozenges and knotted netting are linked diagonally by stretched threads and leaning open areas. Below this are decorative hanging elements, of which 6 survive, consisting of a tube or an open "flower" with 10 pointed petals. This is a single thread structure, the yarn being S-spliced, S-twisted, 2 Z-plied linen. The edges are now ragged and were probably originally a tubular object. Openwork.
Curator's comments: The object cannot be Roman or Coptic due to the spliced yarn. Tamar Schick suggests comparing this object with a similar bag in the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford (labelled 4th Century AD) and the Boston Museum of Fine Art (labelled as 18th Dynasty). Cf. W. M. Flinders Petrie, Qurneh, BSAE 16, (London 1909), pls 27, 28. Information from Hero Granger-Taylor [1995]
Acquisition name: Donated by: Rev Greville John Chester
